column1: Le Pecq (French: [lə.pɛk] (listen)) is a commune in the Yvelines department in the Île-de-France region in north-central France. It is located in the western suburbs of Paris
column2: 18.4 km (11.4 mi) from the center of Paris.

column1: The commune of Le Pecq is located in a loop of the Seine river
column3: at the foot of the chateau of Saint-Germain-en-Laye.

column1: Le Pecq's territory is astride the two banks of the Seine and includes a small island
column2: Corbière. It is highly urbanized except for Corbière island
column3: which is partially protected as a nesting zone for migratory birds. Until after the Second World War
column4: there were swimming baths on the island. Le Pecq was famous for two other establishments related to water: a spa exploiting springs on St-Germain hill and a natural water swimming pool which was 100 metres long with sand beaches.

column1: It borders the communes of Saint-Germain-en-Laye and Mareil-Marly in the west
column2: Montesson and Le Mesnil-le-Roi (Carrières-sous-Bois district) to the north
column3: Croissy-sur-Seine and Le Vésinet in the east and Marly-le-Roi and Le Port-Marly to the south.

column1: The first mention of Le Pecq came in 704.  In that year
column2: the Merovingian king Childebert III granted a charter to Fontenelle Abbey which included territory in Aupec - the modern Le Pecq.
a part of Le Pecq was detached and merged with parts of Chatou and Croissy-sur-Seine to create the commune of Le Vésinet.

column1: Regional center of the "Lyonnaise des Eaux"
column2: water company which produces approximately 90 million cubic meters of drinking water per year
column3: serving approximately 500 000 consumers in the west of Paris.

column1: Home of the Yacht Club of Le Pecq

column3: was built by the architect Sebastien Jan in 1739 on the site of an old church.

column1: Saint-Thibault church: built of concrete and wooden in 1964 by the architects Perrouin
column3: surmounted by an arrow in wood veil 30 height meters.

column2: with iron bridges (later replaced by steel) over the two channels of the Seine
column3: and on the left bank a viaduct of twenty stone arches leading to a tunnel into the cliff at Saint-Germaine-en-Laye

column2: born in Le Pecq on October 9

column1: The town in Le Pecq is notable for being the town of residence of Alain Gournac: Senator of the Yvelines for the Union pour un Mouvement Populaire (UMP) since 1995. A. Gournac also occupied the function of Mayor of the town between 1991 and 2013
column3: following legislature forbidding Senators from also holding the title of Mayor
column5: leaving his seat to Laurence Bernard
column6: also a member of the UMP.

column1: The main transportation links in Le Pecq are the N13 which runs on the left bank of the Seine and secondary road D 186 connecting Saint-Germain-en-Laye with Paris which crosses the Seine at the Le Pecq bridge. This bridge was built in 1963.  It has of flattened steel arches resting on two central concrete piers.
Le Pecq is not served by the Paris Métro
column3: or suburban rail network. The closest station to Le Pecq is Le Vésinet – Le Pecq station on Paris RER line A. This station is located in the neighboring commune of Le Vésinet
column4: 1.2 km (0.75 mi) from the town center of Le Pecq.
